pull.title: rpc: add address_type field in getaddressinfo
pull.body:
While creating and verifying fresh addresses today, noticed it would be helpful to see the address type in RPC getaddressinfo.

Also extracted repeated help docs to a utility helper.

Will add a release note if there are concept acks.

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#28710](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28710) (Remove the legacy wallet and BDB dependency by achow101)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
(Looking for Concept ACKs. Not sure this derives the output type correctly yet.)

Concept ACK
This seems like a useful addition.
Some basic examples below (P2TR, P2WPKH, P2WSH, P2PKH, P2SH)
```
$ src/bitcoin-cli getaddressinfo bc1p8k4v4xuz55dv49svzjg43qjxq2whur7ync9tm0xgl5t4wjl9ca9snxgmlt
{
  "address": "bc1p8k4v4xuz55dv49svzjg43qjxq2whur7ync9tm0xgl5t4wjl9ca9snxgmlt",
  "address_type": "bech32m",
  "scriptPubKey": "51203daaca9b82a51aca960c1491588246029d7e0fc49e0abdbcc8fd17574be5c74b",
  "ismine": false,
  "solvable": false,
  "iswatchonly": false,
  "isscript": true,
  "iswitness": true,
  "witness_version": 1,
  "witness_program": "3daaca9b82a51aca960c1491588246029d7e0fc49e0abdbcc8fd17574be5c74b",
  "ischange": false,
  "labels": [
  ]
}
```

events.message: rpc, test: add "address_type" field in getaddressinfo
init, rpc: use output types helpers for docs
test: add coverage for expected output types in rpc help docs

events.body:
Concept ACK

Including `p2sh-segwit` in `legacy` doesn't look correct.

```diff
-$ bitcoin-cli -regtest getnewaddress "PR30727" "p2sh-segwit"
2MzNJX9GWfZAthZSBdKt6Ja4TF7vBQDi7Uq
```
```diff
$ bitcoin-cli -regtest getaddressinfo 2MzNJX9GWfZAthZSBdKt6Ja4TF7vBQDi7Uq
{
  "address": "2MzNJX9GWfZAthZSBdKt6Ja4TF7vBQDi7Uq",
- "address_type": "legacy",
  "scriptPubKey": "a9144e1f934cd4659c0f47ded79ac1be8fb65c978fe787",
  "ismine": true,
  "solvable": true,
  "desc": "sh(wpkh([e4e21d4d/49h/1h/0h/0/1]030a5b6cf916de338de34a2cab0724b2f7321ed08e84fe092c95e19a84ccac4748))#fkhy0ckw",
  "parent_desc": "sh(wpkh([e4e21d4d/49h/1h/0h]tpubDCjkBmMqh7D5kViEKCaQPi5UP2RyM8VPLGPZh9yjSJiXwCTX1FJbduXkFnQcs8wNFRSx9gLTYsyvjRux5VxK4oufLAPZREqP6MgUhxzuxCP/0/*))#cwslx3xg",
  "iswatchonly": false,
  "isscript": true,
  "iswitness": false,

  "pubkey": "030a5b6cf916de338de34a2cab0724b2f7321ed08e84fe092c95e19a84ccac4748",
  "embedded": {
    "isscript": false,
    "iswitness": true,
    "witness_version": 0,
    "witness_program": "d796c2e4d80f1c0f30c48c661934b797559945c2",
    "pubkey": "030a5b6cf916de338de34a2cab0724b2f7321ed08e84fe092c95e19a84ccac4748",
    "address": "bcrt1q67tv9excpuwq7vxy33npjd9hja2ej3wzhjnmjx",
    "scriptPubKey": "0014d796c2e4d80f1c0f30c48c661934b797559945c2"
  },
  "ischange": false,
  "timestamp": 1724825745,
  "hdkeypath": "m/49h/1h/0h/0/1",
  "hdseedid": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000",
  "hdmasterfingerprint": "e4e21d4d",
```

Are you still working on this?
> Are you still working on this?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -529,6 +531,7 @@ RPCHelpMan getaddressinfo()
                     RPCResult::Type::OBJ, "", "",
                     {
                         {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address", "The bitcoin address validated."},
+                        {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address_type", "The type of bitcoin address; will be one of " + Join(OutputTypes(/*omit=*/OutputType::P2SH_SEGWIT), ", ") + "."},
comments.body: Not sure about mapping the type to an enum that is only used to tell the wallet which descriptors to create. (It only appears as RPCArg, and I think using it in RPCResult is likely wrong). Also mapping p2sh-segwit to the "legacy" bin seems confusing and inconsistent with the input. So effectively this only differentiates between bech32m and bech32. This is fully redundant and less detailed than the already existing `witness_version` field.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -529,6 +531,7 @@ RPCHelpMan getaddressinfo()
                     RPCResult::Type::OBJ, "", "",
                     {
                         {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address", "The bitcoin address validated."},
+                        {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address_type", "The type of bitcoin address; will be one of " + Join(OutputTypes(/*omit=*/OutputType::P2SH_SEGWIT), ", ") + "."},
comments.body: Yup still WIP. It would be nice to provide users with a one-to-one mapping between the input values, supplied to RPC getnewaddress `address_type` and the `-addresstype` and `-changetype` config options, and the same values returned on the other side. If it's feasible, for as you rightly point out, it currently isn't consistent. Pointers welcome.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -529,6 +531,7 @@ RPCHelpMan getaddressinfo()
                     RPCResult::Type::OBJ, "", "",
                     {
                         {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address", "The bitcoin address validated."},
+                        {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address_type", "The type of bitcoin address; will be one of " + Join(OutputTypes(/*omit=*/OutputType::P2SH_SEGWIT), ", ") + "."},
comments.body:
> It would be nice to provide users with a one-to-one mapping between the input values

Again, I think those are different concepts. One is the wallet spkm-type of the built-in wallet, the other is the info returned on an address.

Possibly using decodescript::type could make sense here instead.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -529,6 +531,7 @@ RPCHelpMan getaddressinfo()
                     RPCResult::Type::OBJ, "", "",
                     {
                         {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address", "The bitcoin address validated."},
+                        {RPCResult::Type::STR, "address_type", "The type of bitcoin address; will be one of " + Join(OutputTypes(/*omit=*/OutputType::P2SH_SEGWIT), ", ") + "."},
comments.body: If you want to return the descriptor type of the spkm, maybe it would be better to just return the full parent descriptor of the address instead? This should communicate the type, as well as other details that may be interesting. Though, I am not sure what your imagined use case is.
